review.description:
Autumn is such a wonderful time to indulge in the full bounty of the growing season. Yet another fantastic growing season has again blessed us with so many wonderful food gems. 
Please enjoy pics from my last outdoor visit from this 2018 season. The market is still going on strong and is now nestled indoors for the Winter months.
 
DCFM....see you outdoors on the Mall in Spring 2019.
Happy Holidays to Everyone!
review.author: Carol D.

review.description:
Gorgeous setting and happy vibes.

Overcrowded and most booths don't know how to make a coffee or other item they specialize in. 

Overall a shoving contest and not worth it for me. 

The farmers market off Monona Drive is simple, efficient and less crowded. I'm sticking with ^
review.author: Matt D.

review.description:
Whole lot of cheese curds and veggies 
Good selection of bake goods
Maybe not as much variety as you might think for as many vendors as were there. Seemed like several vendors were selling similar items
review.author: Michael M.

review.description:
ALL OTHER FARMERS MARKETS PALE IN COMPARISON! You have not lived your best farmers market life until you do the one in Madison. I was so spoiled growing up with this! The market is organized around the Capitol building/square and everyone walks in the same direction. You'll be swimming up stream and make people angry if you go the opposite way! Great people watching, fresh produce, beautiful flowers! My cousin's bridal party for married in Madison on a Saturday and picked out their bouquets that morning at the market!

Pro tip: if you go at or before 8am it's not nearly as crowded 

Something to note: I believe they do not allow dogs/pets to be walking around the square when the market is happening 

Favorites: scones from the place that does almost exclusively scones (adore the espresso dark chocolate chip one!), garlic from the garlic man, honey from the guy who wears the beehive hat, cherry bomb hot sauce
review.author: Danielle S.

review.description:
This was my first time at the Dane County Farmer's Market.  I enjoyed it because the weather was cool and sunny.  It wasn't too crowded, especially in the morning.  There was a good variety of vendors.  No beverages really.

My best tip is that the crowd walks counter clock-wise around the capitol.  Make sure you do also!
review.author: Marie N.

review.description:
The Farmer's Market is one of the best things about Madison. Whether you're just in town visiting or are a homegrown Sconnie, this is the place to be on Saturday mornings in the summer.

The vendors wrap all the way around the capitol and food trucks line the streets. It's really incredible supporting local businesses and seeing all of the people that come out! Not to mention, most prices are cheaper than the grocery store, and everything is natural and local so you don't need to pay extra for the organic stuff!

Food isn't the only thing you can buy! but the spicy cheese bread is jaw-droppingly tasty (yes, I know droppingly is not a word). You can get everything from the most stunning bouquets to t-shirts and paintings and even a petting zoo on select weekends!

I would recommend going before 9am, the earlier the better, because once 8:30 hits, it's Disney World-level packed with people. My favorite times at the farmer's market have been around 7am when all of the early birds are there raving about the mushroom haul.
review.author: Lauren J.

review.description: This is a great Madison tradition not to be missed. Stroll, sample, sip and stare at this wonderful sensory spectacle. We try to make this a priority whenever we visit.
review.author: Steve F.

review.description: So there's anything you could want here and it's in such a cool setting.  Loved the huge amount of organic certified booths.  Lots of yummy baked goods and just a nice vibe going on.  So nice strolling the circle around the capital building. The hot &spicy cheese bread is life changing!!  Wish I was from the area to come often.  A must go to if you are visiting on the right day though!
review.author: Susanne V.

review.description: Visited yesterday with a girlfriend who lives in Madison (I live in TX).  I was told I had to try the bread from Stella's, so I did and it was AMAZING!  The farmers market had so much fresh produce!  The farmers market where I live does not compare in the produce section!  This was beyond my expectations.  And all the fresh flowers made the air smell so sweet!
review.author: Brianna C.

review.description: The best of the best in Wisconsin! Incredible local food, but many farmers and gardeners come from very far away and work so hard to get that best to us. But, you just HAVE to go early​ or don't go. Unless you like huge crowds.......
review.author: Junie K.

review.description: Absolutely amazing! It's crazy crowded, but the spices, cheese, and produce are tasty and fresh. Glad we were able to see this during our visit to Madison
review.author: Cassie M.

review.description: I love the farmer's market. One of my favorite things to do during the summer is to take a morning drive out to Madison. There is something for everyone here, fresh fruits and veggies, bakery, honey, maple syrup, flowers... If you haven't been get up early next Saturday and go.
review.author: Carrie L.

review.description:
It's the time of the year when finally the days are getting longer and the weather is getting warmer - which also means another highlight of Madison is about to start. The Dane County Farmer's Market. Once the market start I am a frequent visitor, you can find me always every thing Saturday morning when the weather accompanies.

I go there for produce, anything that is available from vegetables, fruits - every week something different is there, so be prepared to have no plan for your meals, buy what's out there for the week.

My favorites include: tomatoes, honeycrisp apples, cheese curds, peppers, rhubarbs, pickles, honey, jam, mushrooms and also their fresh pasta.

Take cash with you, go early and be prepared to walk slowly. Enjoy your time on the square and get those deals on rainy days. In the fall find all different kinds of pumpkins.
review.author: Stephanie W.
Brittany S.

review.description: Great place to shop. The vendors are amazing people who clearly care for the quality of their product.  If there most get some great WI cheese and fresh baked goods.  Located at the Monona Terrace, makes it a great time to disconnect and enjoy your Saturday morning. Best time to go early to beat the rush.
review.author: Alexandra N.

review.description:
So many yummy things!  Beautiful assortment of fresh produce!!! A must visit!   Stella's Hot and Spicy Cheesy bread is a must!

Stop off and have a look in the capital building too!
review.author: Shan D.

review.description: Honestly if you haven't been to the farmers market downtown you are missing out! I love starting my Saturday mornings here. There is so much to see and try and you are helping local farmers and getting fresh food what could be better. It does get pretty crowded after 9am ish so if you want to beat the rush i would recommend going in before then, if you are a morning person. If you cant/won't go that early it's still okay there will be plenty of food to try and see so taking your time is not a bad idea either.
review.author: Yessenia M.

review.description:
Been fortunate to catch this farmer's market Saturday mornings in Madison which surrounds the capital square the past two times when coming from Chicago. The streets are blocked off surrounding the capital and you're free to circle the square as you like and check out all of the goods being sold. I believe it starts as early at 6am and people are usually all packed up and promptly headed out by 2pm. From the website, this farmer's market runs from April to early November, so take advantage while the weather is nice!

They sell just about everything from cheeses, fresh locally grown produce, cheesy breads, and even a bunch of pop up trailer/food trucks line the block for business. Great spot to bring the family and enjoy the local vibes and lounge on the grassy areas surrounding the capital building. If hanging in Madison for a weekend, this farmer's market on Saturday mornings is a must!

That's about all I got for ya on this one. 'Til next time, cheers!

185/365
review.author: Francis R.

review.description: a madison staple. products change from spring to fall as different crops ripen and become ready for sale, but everything is well worth it. i make sure that any guest coming to visit during farmer's market season spends a morning at the Dane County Farmer's Market eating fresh breakfast buying everything from fresh green beans to honey to homespun yarn, to cherries to soap & sampling fresh goods (cheese curds, cookies, beef sticks, etc). a day well spent!
review.author: Samantha G.

review.description:
The market was fine- very highly rated not much more to add except for one idiosyncrasy which I thought was incredibly ironic considering the location - Madison Wisconsin home of wildly independent thought.  

Apparently there's an unwritten rule that you have to walk counterclockwise around the square as if salmon are running up a river in the spring - God help you if you're going the other direction. You'd think with that many independent thinkers in one spot, a few people may want to go the other direction every now and then... but obviously not, there is no greater fallacy than thinking your unique. If you'd like to see this mystery for yourself - walk clockwise around the square and examine what happens - it could be a new sport.
review.author: Guido V.

review.description:
So many choices at such good prices!  Come early and do one lap first if you can but be mindful of stands you want to go back to and make purchases. 

Don't eat beforehand as you can pick up a fresh and delicious scone or other baked good. 

Local/seasonal fruits and veggies galore.
review.author: Maria A.

review.description:
You won't be able to leave here empty handed! Perfect start to a Saturday morning walking around the square, enjoying the fresh produce and street performers.

This farmer's market circles around the entire capital - the scenery is lovely. There's such a great variety here in fruits, veggies, baked goods, meats, flora, spreads, jam, and cheese! If you get tired, take a seat on the capital lawn and enjoy watching everyone walk through (all the walk the same way too lol the sidewalk isn't large enough for a two way street).

Besides what other reviewers have mentioned (Stella's spicy cheese bread), you must find Savory Accent's booth and at least sample the chili jam!!!! 
So delicious and addicting - consumed about the whole jar in a weekend. It's really that good!
review.author: TD T.

review.description: We are from out of the area but heard great things about this market.   We were not disappointed.  My husband enjoys hot sauces and peppers and found numerous vendors with them.  There was a great variety of items.  If we weren't staying in a hotel we would have purchased the beautiful flower arrangements we saw.  We are glad we put this on our itinerary.
review.author: Lisa H.

review.description:
This is the top five farmer's market in the Country and I can see why! There are fresh vegetables and cheese every where - no so much for the fruit.

My family went on the Wed farmer's market and I went to the Saturday one; you do need to walk counter clockwise,which is confusing when you get there early (I got there around 7:20) because the farmer's market is not that crowded. I was able to two two full browsing loops to select all my veggies and cheeses before it got super crowded around 9. 

Once it became 9 am, everyone and their mother came to the farmers market and it was packed and very overwhelming!

Make sure you shop around, the only thing I regret purchasing was the tomatoes for $4 per LB when i should have opted for the $3.50 per LB tomatoes.

I purchased and traveled with: Blue Cheese, CatNip, Corn, Carrots, Cucumbers, Tomatoes, Bread loaves, and Spicy bread buns.
review.author: Mallory E.

review.description: It took me 4.5 years of living here to FINALLY go to the Farmers' Market -- and I was totally missing out! With one of my close girlfriends and her two littles in strollers, we started the day off at 7:45am. I got some of Stella's spicy cheesy bread, cheese curds from Murph's farms, and some veggies from Yang's. I was definitely impressed with the selections here. I perused several stands with flowers, but just couldn't pull the trigger. They were all beautiful, but maybe next time!
review.author: Jae M.

review.description:
We are lucky to have this nearly year round, from early Spring to late Fall (Winter farmer's market exists!).

You can find anything here, fresh-cut flowers, kimchi, griddle-cooked cheese, pastries, and pastas, the list is endless. I know my prices and the farmer's market isn't outrageous compared to Woodman's prices. Plus, you know that the vegetables are coming from local (and not so local - Door County Cherries?!) area farms.

I like to go early or later for a more tame crowd, but on a gorgeous Autumn day, it's hard to have that type of luxury.

Friends and family that visit from near and far always tell me they want to visit the Dane Co Farmer's Market! They've read it somewhere or have heard it in passing on how great it is.

Make a day of it! Come in the morning and scope out the produce, have lunch on or off State Street and catch some good end-of-the-day specials on your way out!
review.author: Chy R.

review.description: This market makes me happy and is worth the drive from MKE at least once per summer. The tomatoes, Stella's hot and spicy cheese bread, cheese curds, and people watching are the best. Enjoy your stroll around the Capitol and enjoy the freshest treats WI has to offer.
review.author: Torrie B.

review.description:
This is one of the best farmer's markets in all of the land.  It fully encircles the stat's capital building and this layout makes it easy for you to hit all of the vendors and see everyone's wares.  But I do recommend to get their early and you have to get the spicy cheese bread and eat it while shopping for other things.
If you are not aware then I do recommend you look up what is seasonal at the time you visit and talk to the vendors about their wares for recommendations and enjoying them best, especially if it is a food that is new to you.
Taste some samples and once you are done go to Genna's for the bloody Mary bar. Have a lovely day and bring 2 reusable bags!
review.author: Christine D.

review.description:
I had heard great things about the Madison Farmers Market at the Capitol on Saturdays. When I finally found myself in Madison, on a Saturday with some free time before work, I knew where I was going!

I am from Chicago. I've sadly never been to the Green City Market because of traffic and parking. The largest markets I have attended up to now are the Daley Center Market and the Frankfort Farmers market. 

The Dane County Farmers Market is massive. All the way around the Capitol, with craft vendors spilling onto State Street and food trucks across the street from the Capitol. So much to choose from. I got squeaky cheese (because after discovering fresh, I'll never get store bought again), Stella's hot and spicy cheese bread, some croissaint and a rhubarb pie. If I lived locally or was travelling back home after, I would have purchased more fresh products. There was a lot to choose from.

Parking was easy, in my opinion, but I am from Chicago. Parking within a block or two of my destination is close parking, and that is what I found here.
review.author: Julie O.

review.description: If you want to go to a hipster/ artisanal farmers' market this is the place for you.  Despite the homogenous crowd and somewhat high prices this is still one of the better farmers' market I have been to...  but if I lived here I could not imagine doing much shopping here on a regular basis.  I guess I am used to the superb public market in Rochester NY that real people from all walks of life shop at - really more interesting and affordable.  Alas, we don't have the good selection of fresh cheese curds as in Wisconsin!
review.author: PJ C.

review.description: We drove from Delafield to go the the Saturday morning market. That might seem like quite a distance to drive for a farmer's market but this one is worth it! You need to go hungry! Be ready to sample cheese curds. We also broke down and bought pastries. Many many great choices.
review.author: Jo H.

review.description: This is one of the best markets in the state. Not only do they have tons of fresh produce at very reasonable prices they also have a ton of vendors on the various side streets.The market in Madison is just a big event all around. It also has the surreal backdrop of the Capitol building which makes for just a good feeling experience. Madison is a small town but there's so much to do and enjoy. The Farmer's Market is one of those things! If you haven't been you really should go. It's worth the drive even from Milwaukee.
review.author: Chadrick J.

review.description:
I have been a frequent flyer at the downtown Madison Dane County Farmers Market for years! I go for the produce, sweets, fresh floral bouquets and the ambiance. There's just something about an early morning walk around the square while browsing each vendors goods that makes me smile! 

I recommend getting there early, 6:30 - 6:45 AM, to beat the crowds that typically hit around 7:30 AM. The one downside, however, is that several stands do not set up until a bit later in the morning so you may miss out on those by going early. 

If you aren't from Madison (or even if you are), Stella's Monkey Bread and Stella's Spicy Cheese Bread ARE A MUST. Make Stella's your first stop so you can nibble at it as you walk!

Most of the parking ramps have a $5 fee upon entrance. Bring cash, as most vendors do not accept credit cards. No cash? Pop into Walgreens on the square, buy a pack of gum, get cash back = Avoid those ridiculous $5 ATM fees!
review.author: Samantha T.

review.description:
There is a well known fact in Madison.  Saturday at the Capitol Square is home to the most amazing Farmer's Market .  Depending on the time of year, you can find all sorts of edible treasures.  Honey, pastries, and cheese are all season long.  You can easily eat your way around the square and still take some wonderful local produce home with you.  Several food trucks and coffee tents are on the outer corners so there are good eats there too.

It can get a bit crowded after 10:00 am, so be patient.  Bring a basket, bag, or small portable trolley caddy.  Keep a good eye on your kids and dogs, if you need to bring them with you.

Plants and flowers in the spring.  Lettuce, tomatoes, beans in the summer.  Corn, cherries, squash in the fall.  Those are my usual items I pick up.
review.author: Michelle D.

review.description:
Awesome Farmers Market!! Has everything from desserts to fruits and veggies to flowers. All the vendors are great. It's fantastic to buy fresh local and in some cases organic produce! It's very affordable and I never walk away empty handed. It lines the outside of the capitol square and is full of hustle and bustle. I recommend going earlier in the morning when it first opens if you don't like crowds, it gets busier towards the later hours (10-2) and can get really bad depending on the day and the weather. 
Some of my favorite things to pick up are sweet corn, a fresh loaf of bread and some pretty sunflowers. 
Quick tip: bring a large bag to carry around with you and throw all your purchases in!
review.author: Hailey M.

review.description:
Such a fun Saturday experience! The Capitol is already gorgeous and to stroll around it purchasing produce and goods from local farmers makes it even better!

Plenty of things to see and do and a loop around the whole market will take a decent amount of time.
There are a ton of samples from cheese curds to cherry tomatoes and you'll want to buy our the stand after each bite!

Stella's hot spicy cheesy bread is tasty and sinful and definitely worth a try for the experience (but only for newcomers, a bit pricey if you get it every time!) 

Veggies, cheeses, and everything else in between are all decently priced and you'll come home with so much fresh produce!
review.author: Kat W.

review.description:
Really a GREAT farmers market and a great way to spend a Saturday morning... many things can be found here: local honey, local veggies, and lots of local crafts.

The setting at the capitol was a great place (personally I avoided all the political stuff) and it allowed for you to "flow" around the town square and see many vendors.

If you are traveling the area from out of town, like I was, this is a nice and pleasant way to spend a Saturday.
review.author: Troy H.

review.description:
If you ever visit Madison on Saturday, there is no reason, NO REASON, why you could ever miss the farmer's market. It is the heart of Madison. All the wonderful farmers bring their delicious produce and share it with the small town of Madison.

Over 100 farmers gather every week from April to November around the Capitol Square, bringing vegetables, fruits, meat, pastries, eggs, herbs, flowers, anything you can think of to the market! Locals, and visiting guests, come every single week. If you enjoy a slow stroll, and a good selection of produce, come before 9am! 

My favorite things at the market:
Spicy cheese bread - Stella bakery
Blueberries from Flyte family farm
Peaches and cherries from Door County
Graze stand - spinach and mushroom market bun; sausage croissant; magic coffee
Bandaged cheese - Bleu Mont
Apple cider - Ela's orchard

It is just a joy to walk around the square, even if you don't need any groceries. I'm so grateful for this glowing gem in Madison!!
review.author: Ka L.

review.description: I love the Dane County Farmer's Market. Get there early and get there often! It's a perfect way to start a Saturday. Grab a large coffee and stroll around the square. I always go around once to check it all out first. The second trip around the square is to dive in and grab the fruits and veggies that call out to me. Bring cash and a bag for your goodies. While you walk, DO NOT forget to grab a delectable treat for your efforts (both times around the square!). It is hard work foraging for food. Before you leave the square, grab a hot spicy cheese bread for the road. YUM! :)
review.author: Jess N.

review.description: Cheese and fresh procedure and the nice people of Madison! This is definitely an event every Saturday morning that you don't wanna miss. Make sure you buy the famous Stella cheese bread, try all types of cheese from aged cheese to cheese curd to fried cheese, etc. The farmer market also offers great variety of fresh farm produce and beautiful flower bouquet. You can also find great baked goods and delicious snacks. Make sure you have cash in hand because some vendors don't take credit card.
review.author: Tina L.

review.description:
Are you really a Madisonian if you haven't been to the Dane County Farmer's Market and tried Stella's Spicy Cheese Bread?

Tip: Go closer to the end. While things may be a bit picked through, the crowds are much smaller and you will find better deals as farmers want to get rid of their haul before close.
review.author: Jessica G.

review.description:
I must admit that when I first moved to Madison and went to the farmer's market, I was overwhelmed and didn't enjoy myself. I thought the market was too huge and too busy. Now that I've gone to the market for a few years, I feel a little lost on the Saturdays that I don't go. It's become a habit, and I like it.

The selection of items offered by the farmers at the market is wonderful: I can buy fruit, veggies, meat, smoked fish, a bouquet, soap, honey, syrup, jams, cheese and some plants for landscaping all in one fell swoop.

I don't recommend going to the trouble of driving downtown, parking, buying blueberries, then leaving. Make your market trip a morning outing. Enjoy breakfast or brunch at a downtown restaurant along with your market visit.

I now make it a point to take out-of-town guests to the market when they visit Madison!
review.author: Lauren H.

review.description:
My favorite weekend activity! Lovely place to walk around in the morning and pick up some herb plants, baked goods and honey! At least, that's what I do :) Like the other reviewers will say, go early. As in, before 9am preferably. After that, the street gets packed full of people and little kids running around everywhere. Even so, being in the busy crowd isnt too bad because you also get to slow down and look at things as well. 

Get your honey from Marsdens honey! You can't miss him, he's in a giant beehive hat. Very friendly guy, always willing to advise new customers on the types of honey he has, and not to mention, the honey is indeed good! 

Lots of cheese samples, flower stands, and freshly baked goods. Be prepared, most places are cash only!! There's a couple of banks around the square, though they may not be surcharge free.
review.author: Alysia C.

review.description:
Bring your cash, because the food will definitely suck you in! From the delicious baked goods - I'm a cookie monster and I can't leave without Stella's Spicy Bread - to the cheeses and my favorite bee man (the one with the hive hat), this is a definite must-go place if you happen to be in Madison on a Saturday. 

Parking is a little tricky sometimes, but it's totally worth the road frustration. Also, I'd like to caution the people who don't like crowds of people and walking at a snails pace; it can get a little claustrophobic at times with people inside your bubble (but you can't help that).
review.author: Crystal K.

review.description:
This place is a must if you're visiting the area for the first time. Actually, if I lived here I would probably go here a lot. It's a huge farmers market where you are buying directly from the farmer. I loved seeing the eccentric personalities of these locals sharing their products with the public. 

   There was a huge variety of items for sale. Of course there are the fresh fruits and vegetables but there were also potted herbs, cheese, noodles, meats, oils, sauces, flowers etc. There were also a couple of tents selling fresh breads and cookies. I split the feta and spinach empanada from Stella's. It was pretty good. A little pricy tho. We also purchased some veggies for meals, raspberries and Macintosh apples. They tasted fresh. 

   The market runs along the square. I saw some reviews recommending to get there early for parking and to avoid the crowd. Maybe I was lucky but we were there around 10 and while yes there was a crowd I still felt comfortable enough to shop. It may or may not have had something to do with it being Iron Man weekend. We tried to find street parking but settled for the $5 parking in a nearby parking garage.
review.author: Katrina B.

review.description:
There is nothing more to add onto the great reviews of the largest producer only outdoor market in the country.  It is amazing and a Saturday ritual for me since I have been back in Madison for the past 10 years.  Here are some tips for newbies:

1)  Walk counter-clockwise with the other 99.8% of the people that have a clue.
2)  Try to get there before 9 am.  After that, it becomes a cattle call.
3)  Unless you have a gaggle of kids, leave the wagon at home.  Yes, it is kinda cute but super awkward to get around. 
4)  Gawking is ok but if you are doing so, try to keep it at a minimum.  Doing so only backs up your fellow shoppers.  And let's face it, we have all seen tomatoes, zucchini. and basil before.
5)  Try not to smoke while walking.  Remember where you are and the people around you.  The person behind you probably has dreadlocks and walking barefoot and will mean mug the shit outta you for doing so.
review.author: Bobb S.

review.description: Love coming back once a summer to visit this Farmers Market.  Puts all other markets to shame.  Great samples, fresh eats, so many tasty bakery treats, and food trucks.  I was slightly disappointed how expensive stellas spicy cheese bread is now!!!  Decided to boycott this year - I think I was the only one though as the lines were still quite long.  Also note to self - if you come between 9 and 11 leave the stroller at home...heck probably leave the kid at home - way too busy.
review.author: Sara O.

review.description:
Here is your to-do list at the Dane County Farmer's Market:
- sample all of the cheese, in all forms
- Stella's hot cheesey bread, best eaten fresh though it travels well too
- try and buy jams and pickles; I can't wait to use my pickled asparagus in a bloody mary 
- check out the flowers, many beautiful and affordable choices 
- people watch
review.author: Cherine F.

review.description: I really like the Dane County Farmer's Market.  There are tons of great vendors.  If you have any questions, in my experience just ask.  They will give great advice.  There are tricks and tips to any market.  What time of year or time of day to go.  Yes, it is an amazing market and attracts many people, yes, it gets congested.  If you don't like a ton of people and want the best selection go early.  If you want a deal on the left overs go late.
review.author: James N.

review.description:
Come here with the patience of a saint and you'll have a good time. I would not recommend coming here with any of the following attributes : short-time frame, fatigue, hungover, with kids-especially little kids, strollers, dogs, or cats. People will be people and act like people in a big crowd : expect people to stop suddenly in front of you or kids cutting in and out between the sidewalk and greens around the capital. I cannot tell you how many people I hear from time to time angry at how crowded it is - deal with it or just stay home; you're really not helping and there isn't anything you can do to change probably 3000+years of human behavior in crowds. I only knock off a star because of this admitted fact - maybe the space isn't great for the amount of people but it is what it is.

Parking is fortunately very merciful due to all the parking garages and nearby streets. I tend to park in the same place and do the same loop for memory sakes and avoid any unforseen issues. 

For myself, some of the items that stand out to me :

Frozen Corn Chowder (I can't remember the stand but there is one that sells frozen corn chowder and its GREAT). I'm not sure if it's still around for 2016 but I really enjoyed it in 2015.

The Cheese Stands. If you love cheese, there is plenty to be found. Brunkow is a big one with the most variety and largest crowds due to the free samplers but there is also the notable Hooks amongst many others that might have smaller crowds.

Cheap as heck Spinach, vegetables. Really, the prices are much better than the grocery store - especially on spinach.

The homemade tortillas. There is a stand that sells homemade flour tortillas that I really enjoy. They have a variety of breads also. One of the few stands(maybe the only one) that sells this type of product.

Stellas - Everyone likes the spicy cheese bread! 

R&P Pasta - I like the variety of "take home and make" fresh pastas they sell. I believe its cheaper than if you buy it in the store. (One of the few that accepts credit card last I was there)

Mushrooms - Not sure on the exact stand but its smaller and sells a few mushrooms I've never seen elsewhere such as Lion's Mane mushrooms.
review.author: Joshua J.

review.description:
This is the promised land for those who love a good farmer's market.  It's the largest in the country and the sheer number of vendors and the variety of goods they are selling is amazing.  The fresh vegetables stand out, as do the cheese curds and baked goods.  Some pretty decent street entertainment about a block from the square in any direction.

Be prepared for a crowd.  Also, bring a blanket to sit in the shade and take a break now and then....no point in trying to rush through it, because you can't.
review.author: Bill J.

review.description: I have been coming here for years and I love it. The vendors are very nice there is a large variety of produce. Fresh flowers. Etc this is the best farmers market around. I can not say enough. Stella's bakery is yummy and the aroma of the fresh herbs is something you will like .
review.author: Ginger P.

review.description: OH EM GEE. Farmer's Market Heaven! Wrapped around the entire Capitol Square and spilling into the surrounding streets, this is the best farmer's market I have ever been to! Lots of amazing looking fruits and veggies, baked goods, tons of fresh flowers, artisan ingredients, handmade crafts, and more. Traffic moves in one direction, so make sure you step to the side if you are considering an item - you can't salmon-swim against the crowd to backtrack if you change your mind! Well worth getting up early for, and the Capitol building is air-conditioned if you need to duck in out of the heat as well.
review.author: Rachel R.

review.description: There is not much to add to the already glowing reviews of this market. I've been to many a farmer's market, and this one, at least in summer around the Capitol Square, has the most variety, quality and great prices for local farm products I've ever seen. Some Farmer's Market have quality goods but are just too expensive. That is not the case here. The availability of eat-and-go items like Stella's give it a real European feel. While crowded it is navigable and fun to stroll through for a couple of hours. Winter it moves indoors in two different venues, with a smaller number of vendors;still a great resource if you're looking for reasonably-priced, fresh ingredients. Vendors are usually helpful and friendly, too.
review.author: Jack P.

review.description:
Radish, rhubarb, cheese curd. Radish, rhubard, cheese curd. Radish, rhubarb, cheese curd.

I think it was a mixture of my having been to very few farmer' markets + reading all the reviews and likening it to adult Disneyland, that made for my being disappointed in the Dane County Farmer's Market. 

I guess I should just be happy that it was a nice day even though the weather forecast called for rain. But with that sunshine came droves of slow walking, stroller pushing stop in the midst of a moving crown and gawk while shoving food in your mouth crowds. 

The scene was lovely and the square held such potential for what businesses and goods I'd find inside, but really, I found a lot of the same ish at 85% of the tables. We did get some cheese curds from a place a Wisco lad said was the absolute best (but I'd had better when a friend brought back the dill curds from another vendor at the very same fair), but other than that, it was really just a fair for plants and people selling radishes and rhubarb. How many things can you make out of radish and rhubarb as the main ingredient? Is this a Wisco thing? Because I don't think we Illini have put much stock in the dietary nourishment of radishes and rhubarb as a main ingredient.

I guess after having been to farmers market out in the SoCal area, it's probably hard to compare, but is this one really all that much superior to other farmer's markets? Maybe I went on an off day but I just wasn't as excited as I expected to be. I'll go again, but I'll have more level expectations this time, for sure.
review.author: Candice G.

review.description:
I'm a fan of absolutely everything about this market, except the crowds.

Love the location.  Madison is a beautiful city and the Capitol Square is a great backdrop for the amazing vendors and their wares.  The event is extremely organized and I like how the foot traffic flows in the same direction.  The market website is an excellent source of information and I love that I could elect to receive a newsletter each week with updates on the seasonal information and steady favorites.

The fringe vendors and food carts and flea market type tables across all four streets on the square add to the charm and vibe and value of the day.  And the breakfast and brunch dining options all within walking distance, and some with a great view of the market, are plentiful.

The vendors are wonderful people that love to tell you as much as you'd like to know about their goods.  Today I learned the best conditions for growing and foraging ramps, how allusive they can be, how they seed themselves and how short the season is.  Great lesson.   

Another important thing many vendors will share is best times to shop.   When I arrived at 8:15am the market was in full swing and the crowd was shoulder to shoulder.  I now know why the market opens at 7am - the first hour is the best hour to shop.  Veteran market goers shared that the 12:30-2pm slot usually presents a thinner crowd, but also less selection.  So pick your poison, early to rise, or claustrophobia inducing crowds.
 
And  bring a big basket or bag because you'll find so many things, even some you didn't know you need.
review.author: Carrie G.

review.description: This farmers market is so amazing. The market it's self is laid out beautifully. The flow of traffic makes sense as vendors are on the outside of the square which makes it easy to view wares and move along.  There is so much produce! As someone who loves vegetables, I had an education today. I learned about Dragon tongue beans, bitter eggplant, and a host of other unique and different veggies.  Vendors were very happy to talk about their products and it was such a positive and interactive experience.  Go hungry! There are food trucks all around and I was super disappointed that we had eaten breakfast before we ventured around.  The flowers are beyond beautiful. Gladiolas and hydrangea are blooming right now and the bouquets of beautiful colors, shapes and sizes are a feast for the eyes. Also included in the bevy of items for purchase are jams, jellies, sauces and pickled vegetables. We bought a pint of pickled beets for my salads and some raspberry habanero and blackberry raspberry jam. All are available for tasting and so pleasing to my palate! We are in Wisconsin after all, so we can't forget about the cheese!!! So many vendors sold cheese curds and other cheeses. We bought a chive horseradish havarti and a five-year-old cheddar. Cannot wait to make a grilled cheese with the five-year-old cheddar and the raspberry habanero jam!!  Finally, the baked goods look so amazing I can't even take it. My husband and I bought a bag of blueberry granola and a mini orange chocolate chip loaf for breakfast this week.  Overall, it was a great experience and I compare it to my favorite place on earth which is the Boulder farmers market in Colorado. I have to say that this one is better because it's laid out nicer, the prices are cheaper, and the vendor products are more diverse.  I would definitely come up here for a weekend again with my husband and enjoy this farmers market. Next time I'll bring a cooler so that we can bring home the pesto and try many of the meats that are sold!!  Good job, Madison. A+
review.author: Meredith C.

review.description:
Summer. 
Fresh.
Local.
Stella's Hot and Spicy Cheese Bread. 

Madison, WI is the best.
review.author: Meghan H.

review.description:
There's a very good reason that the Dane County Farmers' Market routinely appears on many top ten lists of best markets in the country--it's tops in every category.

The market takes place on the square surrounding the state Capitol; the setting so picturesque and the vendors so plentiful, that it's in a class by itself.

So much bountiful produce that it's staggering; so many varieties of baked goods that it's mind-blowing; and tons of other odds and ends (spices, maple syrup, jams/jellies) to tantalize and delight you.

You'll find all walks of life at the market. Everyone from hippies to grandmas to college students. It's a true sea of humanity.

This market boasts the best of everything. The vendors here supply the top restaurants in Madison and the Midwest. 

Totally worth getting up at the crack of dawn (even while on vacation) to check this out.
review.author: Melanie S.

review.description:
The farmer's market is a sh!t show of gargantuan proportions. If I weren't so addicted to Bushel & Peck's pickled beets I'd never go back. It's gotten to the point that I think driving to Beloit to get the damned beets would be a better option than going to the farmer's market. 

What I really need is a pickled beet runner. Watch for my gofundme campaign.
review.author: Jen W.

review.description:
It's just as good as all of the reviews you've read.
It really is.   It lives up to the hype from in towners and out of towers.
Seasonal, Wisconsin local products, beautifully arranged and sold directly to you.
I like to go early before the masses to actually be able to touch, feel and smell the produce.  Talk to the farmers, bakers, and growers of these plants, veggies, breads and oh so much more.
Sample goat's cheese, heirloom tomatoes, purchase walnuts, bison meat sticks, beautifully decorated cookies, hand crafted breads, its all there for the taking.
Want to see what Wisconsin has to offer?  Come here to see the bounty.

Winter indoor market is fun too but a whole different bird.  My first lover was the summer market, so while winter market will do, I can't forget my first kiss.
review.author: Rowan C.

review.description: I love this farmers market. It is so big and the selection of produce, bread, seasoning, honey etc is extraordinary.  I had to walk around 2 times before I decided on several items. This farmers market is reasonable and great quality. I purchased bread, honey, zucchini, squash, and seasoning.  I could barely fit everything in my suitcase. If I had a complaint about the market it would be it's only on Saturday. I would love for it to be open on Sunday.  I know that I am greedy though.  This farmers market has more veggies then fruit so that would be something to keep in mind. Or at least when I went there.
review.author: Tae S.

review.description: The epitome of "Farmers Market." This is the best. Everything is certified organic and local. Plus the location surrounding the Wisconsin State Capitol can't be beat. Get out there with the thousands of other people and see why this is the best. My top pick: Pilgrim's Pantry raspberry handheld pies.
review.author: Mitchell F.

review.description:
This is definitely the best and the largest farmers market I have ever been to. The prices were reasonable and there were variety of items to buy! I had bought a full week groceries from there while my friends bought a couple of cheese items. Two of my friends and I were visiting a friend and madison and we stumbled upon this market. I really liked the ambience and the layout of the market since it was all around the capital building, and it was really organized!

The flowers that people sold were absolutely gorgeous. Overall, I wish that we had such an amazing farmers market in Chicago!
review.author: Maggi K.

review.description:
Some sage advice: Go early. Like...7am early.

For me, it doesn't matter if I drank an entire keg the night before--you can bet that I'll happily drag my groggy, hungover ass out of bed at 6:45am so I can get to the Farmers' Market by 7. Otherwise, you get stuck in the nonstop shuffle of zombies, moving at a snails' pace. Oh, and when it's crowded, you can't talk to the farmers! Trust me, it's the best part.

So, my routine: one lap to scope out what's in season and to compare prices (yes, I am a Jew...literally). Lap two to purchase everything I want. Lap 3 for cleanup--anything I missed! It takes about an hour, but again--totally worth it.

Why is it so spectacular? Everything is locally grown and very, very fresh. The produce are phenomenal (as I nom on a tomato I bought this morning). Cheese is wonderful--especially Hook's! The meat is also great! I mean...really, can you do much better?

The farmers' market is a foodie's dream, and is definitely one of the things I'll miss when I leave Madison! Now, if I only I could convince people to stay away from the spicy cheese bread (really, it's just not very good)...
review.author: Dylan K.

review.description:
Impressive, we walked all the way around the capital in search of vegan donuts for my sister, we didn't find them, but did find lots of other really good treats.  Loved the cherry pastries with frosting.  Cow petting is good for kids, just seems so silly to have to go right to the steps of the state capital in order to see cows that live all across the state.

Beware, officially the closing time is 2, but by 2 almost everything is broken down.  I wonder if it would be draconian to insist that everyone go in only one direction.
review.author: John C.

review.description:
I've been to farmers' markets around the country, in Canada, and in Europe, and the only thing any of them have got over Madison's is, well, things that you just can't get at such a market in Madison, because they are made elsewhere, and the Dane County Farmer's Market has rules about where the goods available there are provenanced.  From difficult-to-find heirloom fruit varieties to the freshest vegetables, to that family who still crack local black walnuts or hickory-nuts, to fresh baked goodies, young plants in spring, Willi Lehner's yodeling cheese stand, to that friend you haven't seen for a few years and run into at the market.  Go often, go early, avoid the crowds, the dogs, the strollers, and the slow-movers.  Note that the "norm" at this market is to go around the square in a counter-clockwise flow.  For those who might lack the spatial perception to figure out what that means, the capitol building will be on your left as you walk along, the streets and vendors on your right.  The market has an faq page on its website, at:  http://dcfm.org/faq/

A note for animal owners:  Pets, except service animals, are not allowed on the Square during the Saturday Market per Capitol ground rules.

It is also useful to note that the market participates in the Food Share program, so for those with what is archaically called "food stamps" benefits, your EBT card may be accepted somehow by the vendor you want to buy from.  In 2015, Dane County Farmers' Market customers spent $49,234.00, the most federal food assistance dollars of any market in Wisconsin.  More information on that may be found here: http://dcfm.org/foodshareebt/
review.author: Michael H.

review.description: It doesn't get much better than the Dane County Farmer's Market! Stella's hot and spicy cheese bread is an obvious must when visiting. My personal favorite cheese stand was Brunkow's (all the samples!) and Hook's for purchasing cheese! D&G also has some amazing beefsticks and jerky! I lived in madison for 9 years and it never got old!
review.author: Pat L.

review.description:
This is probably the best farmer's market I've been to. It's open every Saturday from early morning till around 2 pm-ish. When it gets cold in November, the farmer's market is moved indoors. 

You can find almost anything here and everything is cheap. I frequented Dane County Farmer's Market quite often to get fruit and vegetables. Occasionally, I would treat the fiancee to a nice batch of flowers. My favorite edibles are the kettle corn stop, honey sticks, meat sticks, and best of all Stella's bakery for the spicy cheese bread. 

When friends from out of town come to visit, I always bring them to the farmer's market and they genuinely have a good time here. You can also tour the capital building if you get bored enough.
review.author: Tunaidi A.

review.description: I drove 2 1/2 hours from Illinois to go to the Farmers Market, it was huge! If you like fresh fruits and veggies this is the place for you. Me, I don't eat fresh fruits and veggies, I don't care if it is gluten free, GMO free or healthy. The prices vary on everything so look around and compare prices.  I did buy some herbs and bedding plants and got a good price.  What I would like to see is more non-farmer vendors and more deep fried, fatty food vendors. They also do not allow dogs at the Market.  I would say let dogs in but ban those people who are pushing around those strollers or the people who let their kids run around and run into people.  Dogs are much better behaved.
review.author: Missy R.

review.description:
This farmer's market puts all other farmer's markets to shame. Besides taking place on the grounds of the beautiful Wisconsin State Capitol Building, it has a HUGE selection of anything grown or made. Numerous fresh veggie, cheese, baked goods, and local honey stands. You can even buy high quality, locally sourced cured meats and fresh meats. Speaking of cheese, you can find some of the freshest and tastiest squeaky cheese curds courtesy of Farmer John. And many of these items are very affordable, especially veggies that are at the end of their season.

Whereas other farmer's markets might have one or two of a stand that sells a particular product, this one can have a half dozen or more just selling pumpkins or baked goods or whatever your heart desires. If I lived nearby, I'd be here every Saturday that I could be.
review.author: Shea S.

review.description:
Welcome to Stepford for local, organic, and quality produce shopping. 

Basically, once you step foot on the sidewalk that surrounds the Capitol, you are instantly swept in a one way direction scoping out the freshest gigs that help clean your colon and baked goods that increase the waist line.

 It was definitely an experience getting caught up in the momentum and great seeing so many people getting excited for local and organic goods. We left with one of the best brownies I have had in a long time and almost walked away with a potted parsley plant. 

My one critique, invest in Square space peeps! I cut the Amish table some slack but only one stand, out of four full blocks worth, had credit card capabilities. I appreciate the charm of using cash but I would have bought a ton more if I could swipe it.
review.author: Kaitlyn F.

review.description: Definitely go if you love crowds of slow moving meandering people, wagons, giant behemoth strollers. If you don't, then still go, but go EARLY. The one and only reason I go there is Cherokee Bison meats. Everything else I can get elsewhere, without the frustration, paying for parking, getting up at the crack of dawn, and endless slow walking. It's definitely one of the Madison things you should do at least once. Great selection, no complaints there...it's just too crowded for me.
review.author: Sarajane L.

review.description: The vendors are great and there is a lot to choose from. Unfortunately, the experience can be maddening if you are not a snail.  People tend to move at a slow, ambling pace.  Several have strollers.  Some stop abruptly and block other foot traffic.  Others will group around a booth without intending to purchase from that vendor, but blocking the true line.  I would love to see "lanes" implemented at the market but don't think that will ever happen.  Until then my best bet is to go early and/or during poor weather.
review.author: K K.

review.description:
I have heard so much about the Madison Farmer's market.  I am taking one star away because I have visited the Farmer's Market in Minneapolis, which has a little more variety and better traffic for walking.   That said, we did enjoy the market and intend to go back.  The flowers were probably one of my favorites; good pricing for some tall and bright flowers.  Aside from tons of organic veggies, fruit, honey, and meat, they had other interesting foods there.  We crossed the street to take advantage of some of the food carts selling good ethnic food.  I wish they had more carts like this, to compliment the farmer's market.  It doesn't have to be all food trucks, but a little more arts, perfumes... and other things would improve it even further.  

Food trucks:  Vietnamese Tacos:  So good!   Gyro Food Truck:  shawarma gyro was so amazing.  

Steinke's popcorn:  many different flavors.  It was interesting trying Peanut Butter and Jelly Popcorn.  Just for fun.  

Potter's Crackers:  A little overpriced, but we bought it anyway b/c it was so good.  We bought the Rye crackers (with some other flavor blended in).  Super good and it would make a good gift for someone (hostess gift...).


The only disappointment I had was the Stellas Spicy Cheese Bread.  I thought it was going to be great, given all the reviews here.  We paid $9 for this, thinking it was going to be awesome.  The bread was huge, so I thought it would be something with leftovers between two people.   I was not impressed.  It tasted good, but was way overpriced.  It was a huge bread and I thought it was going to be stuffed with cheese (hence the leftover thought).  I was wrong.  It was about 90% bread, stuffed with a small amount of cheese.  If you wanted the cheese (hence the name for the bread), you have to eat (or throw away like we did) a ton of bread.  Most of the loaf bread only.  There was some cheese, but very little.  The bread tasted good, but given that it was basically a whole big bread with a tiny bit of cheese, I would say that it wasn't even close to demanding $9 per loaf.   Think about it, how much would you pay at a bread shop for a big loaf of bread?  That is what you should pay for this.  I have a feeling (and confirmed by other reviews on Stellas) that it used to be really good, they became popular, tried to cut their cost and cut the quality with it.  Totally overrated.  

Tips:  Parking ramp nearby on Main Street, bring CASH!!  Limited people take credit card, walk in the one direction the rest of the crowd is going.  It's a one way direction only.  If you want to walk faster, move to the left.  Slower, move to the right.  Leave the strollers/wagons at home if you can b/c it's tight during the peak hours and people will get annoyed with your wheels.   I was told no dogs, but I saws  few, barking at the others.  Leave the dog at home so you don't have to fuss over him/her.   Bring bottled water if you plan on eating as you shop the stands.
review.author: Jennifer M.

review.description:
Going to the farmer's market on Saturday is pretty much turning into a ritual for me. It is such a fun way to start the weekend. 

The produce is great, I bought some cherry tomatoes one weekend and I never want to buy them from the store again. I did not realize how good fresh tomatoes can taste. It takes a lot of restraint to not buy Stella's cheesy bread but if you have people visiting do buy your guests some! I also have seen an emu meat vendor. Can't say I've tried that yet. Herbs are great to purchase here they are usually a $1 for a handful. Great deal.

Parking- I usually park in one of the garages around the square, the farmer's market really only takes about an hour to do a lap so you won't be paying more than a buck or two for parking. Or you can always park a little further maybe 4 blocks away if you are willing to walk and then parking is free.

Walk in the SAME direction everyone else is walking. It will make your life easier.
review.author: Samantha S.

review.description:
I've been going to the Dane County Farmer's Market regularly since I moved to Madison over 15 years ago, and it's never disappointed me.

If you want prime pickins', you need to get there early (7am or earlier), but even those who like to sleep in a little should have no problem finding all sorts of tasty seasonal things to eat all summer long.

I challenge myself and find something I don't eat regularly to try out at least a few times a summer.

Raw fruits and veggies are the norm, but there are also a number of meat vendors, many with baked goods and preserves, dried seasonings, and a couple honey vendors as well. At the top of State Street, there are also a number of art and craft vendors with beautiful, handmade wares for you to purchase (I was one of them for six years!) - from jewelry and glasswork to handmade soaps and clothing.

The crowds can get a bit crazy, especially during peak hours, so don't plan on trying to push a stroller or large cart through the main thoroughfare (your fellow shoppers will thank you, and your frustration level will drop exponentially.) 

The market officially closes at 2pm, but don't plan on going late -- most farmers are sold out of their goods and packing up by a bit after 1pm, depending on weather and crowds.
review.author: Alyska B.

review.description:
Dane County Farmers Market on Saturday morning is a great way to start out the day. I love to go - choose my breakfast there and walk around the square to see the different products, and who has the best prices.  I try to buy organic foods, which is nice to get at the market, it is much less expensive than getting at the store. If there are other events downtown, free parking can be very difficult to find.  The earlier you go, the less crowded.  I didn't give 5 stars because I personally don't like large crowds.  It is becoming more and more a tourist type attraction - so being a local, when I'm there to get a couple of things and leave - it's not so easy.
The vendors are great and easy to talk to.  Great  variety of products on the square. I enjoy getting fresh eggs there :)
review.author: Michelle H.

review.description:
This was my first visit to the Dane County Farmer's Market and I was very impressed. The mere size of this market is mind blowing especially in the setting around the beautiful Capitol. The variety of fresh goods is amazing. 

Be prepared for the slow-moving crowds and almost all cash only vendors.
review.author: Kristy D.

review.description:
I feel pretty lucky that Indianapolis provides me with a large selection of farmer's markets to choose from, a significant portion of which I have been a visitor of, but nothing comes close to the awesomeness that is the Dane County Farmer's Market. That being said, if a farmer's market only had one stand that sold one item, and it happened to be Stella's selling their spicy cheese bread, I would still think it was the best farmer's market in existence. More on that later.

After a slow start due to a member of our crew being almost entirely incapacitated by excessive drinking that was done on Friday night, we finally headed out the market. Madison is a very friendly city to those seeking to get places either by foot or by bike, and we had no trouble walking to the towering capital building sitting in the center of town. We were actually lucky enough to have picked a day to visit when they had a lot of State St. closed off for a car show. I don't know how often they do this, but it was a lot of fun to get to see on the way there. My visit was on the first weekend of June, and the weather was perfect and people were taking advantage of it. The crowd was kind of large around 11:30, but it wasn't too hard to get around in. The square of vendors lining the sidewalk around the capital building was pretty easy to navigate and see everything that they had to offer. It seems that the crowd arranges itself to have fast walkers on the outside and slow walkers next to the stands, and it worked out pretty conveniently.

There was a large selection of veggies at the time that we were there. A lot of these are the seasonal items that are in peak season, so many stands have the same options. I would recommend taking the time to walk around a little, because I noticed significantly different prices for the same items. Along with plenty of fresh foods included a plethora of bakeries, lots of butchers that sold both raw meats (including venison and emu) and cooked meats like jerky and meat sticks that you could eat while walking, all kinds of honey places, plenty of canned fruits and vegetables, and lots of plants and fresh flowers. This would be a great place to get potted veggies to transfer to a garden. There is certainly no shortage of foods to get from the local farms to satisfy your hunger on the spot, but if you want something more substantial, there are a ton of food trucks that are on the outside of the square and provide many more options. Once you get some food to eat, or if you just decide to enjoy the weather and take a break, there is an abundance of seating area in the huge grass lawn in the center of all of the vendor's tents. I'd suggest bringing a blanket, as it'd be a great place to have a picnic in the sun or under the shade of one of the many trees. 

The pièce de résistance, at least in my opinion, came in the form of a huge loaf of soft warm bread stuffed with melty cheese and covered with red pepper flakes served in a plastic bag that was well worth waiting the long line for. I'd been told by many people that this couldn't go unpurchased if I made it here, and I'm glad I waited in the ever-growing line as they waited on a fresh shipment from the bakery to arrive. The place was called Stella's, and while all of their other items looked good, this artery clogging medley of carbs and cheese was the item I'd suggest getting, especially if you are trying to fight off a hangover. 

I don't know what parking looks like around there, but I'd certainly recommend walking or biking if either of those is an option. I didn't see any ATMs set up at the market, but there was a Chase bank close to the location and we stopped there on the way to get cash. Make sure you bring a large bag, because odds are that you will leave with more than you expected to when you arrived.
review.author: Dylan E.

review.description:
Best. Farmer's. Market. Ever.

I love everything about this market, even the crowds (because really, they just reflect how awesome it truly is). Wonderfully nice vendors with an assortment of produce, meats, cheeses, and other goodies. I visited the market again last week (mid-September) and the flower arrangements were gorgeous. Stella's spicy cheese bread is my must-have guilty pleasure- just be prepared for the lines!
review.author: Kelsey S.

review.description:
I love farmer's markets in general, but Dane County Farmer's Market has taken it to another level. Imagine how beautiful the square is surrounding the State Capitol. Then add a bunch of tents with awesome goods all around it, and you've got a recipe for success. 

We started our trip to the Farmer's Market with a spicy cheesy bread from Stella's so that we could nibble on it as we walked around the square. That plus all the samples of cheese becomes a pretty satisfying brunch for the day. To make sure had some veggies in us, we bought some sweet snap peas to snack on as we walked. 

Highlights
- Stella's hot cheesy bread: a massive sweet challah bread with red chilli pepper flakes on the top and warm soft cheese in the middle. Get them while they're hot if you can! 
- Cheese samples galore! 
- Fresh produce: lots of tomatoes, onions, lettuce, etc
- The Herb market has shelves of various types of basil, rosemary, thyme, dill, etc
- Fresh kettle corn made in front of your eyes
- Small desert plants for your office (requires very little care)
- Beautiful flower arrangements from local florists
- A Gluten free bakery called Silly Yak Bakery (Celiac disease)
- The cute boutique booths across from the square. Especially Spoon Rings!! (make finger rings out of antique spoons)
- Watching people do yoga in the grass
- Being able to go visit the inside and top of the Capitol

Hours
Saturdays Jan thru Mid-April: 8am-noon
Saturdays Mid-April thru Nov: 6am-2pm
Wednesdays Mid-April thru Nov: 8:30am-2pm
Saturdays Nov thru Mid December: 7:30am-noon

Tip: Move in a counterclockwise direction to go with the flow
review.author: Joy D.

review.description:
Let me spell it out for you.

C. L. U. S. T. E. R. F. U. C. K.

How anyone could honestly shop here astounds me.
I literally felt like cattle being pushed through a small walkway.

Pro's.
-Astounding selection
-Great people watching.

That's about it.

Con's.
-How does anyone move?! Don't even dare try to go back from the direction you came as you will be walking into a literal wall of people.
-You can't comparative shop as you can barely get to the vendors, let alone find them once again after you've passed them.
-Rude yuppies.
-Rude yuppies with strollers.
-Rude yuppies with strollers and 1200 reusable trader joe bags that hit you as you try to pass them.

I get that there is some wonderful product here, but the set up and sheer massive quanity of people that show up really created an un enjoyable experience for me.
review.author: Rachael G.

review.description:
Although, I am a fan let me say the only drawback about this whole "situation" (if you watch Kevin Hart you'll know what that means, lol) the INFORMATION BOOTH HAS NO IDEA OF VENDOR LOCATIONS. 

What do I mean? Well, the folks at the info booth can't tell you (1) where to find a specific vendor - by name, nothing (2) DO NOT HAVE A MAP LAYOUT OF THE VENDORS AT THE BOOTH and looked sincerely confused when I asked. I'm laughing now but it sure wasn't funny then and (3) don't appear to be interested in creating a vendor booth map for any specific ryhme or reason. 

I guess I'll do it. And in crayon so it's festive =) 

You have to get in even earlier nowadays to beat the crowd. It used to be at 7am - no one was there but the chefs/sous chefs & elderly elderly.

Now, at 7am I'm rushing. 
It's as if the intervals have been pushed ahead like daylight savings. 
11am - used to be stroller time but they're getting in around 9a and staying until closing. 
12noon/1p is the college crowd time, but get this..... that's the best time to go, if you want to get deals. I mean folks start to shut down but by 2pm no haggling needed. Just take it. 
However, if it's what you want you had better get in early. The good stuff has caught on and folks are selling out. ....

5 stars for Dane County Farmer's Market for making fresh food available to middle america families that has to use WIC/US AID/Food Stamps and any other voucher program. Which is what moves my would be 3 - star A-OK. rating to a 4 star I'm a fan. Besides the offerings being redundant...it somehow works. And I'm not a "CHOPPED" type cook. I decide what I want to eat then get the ingredients. Now, I'll plan for a week or even longer but you can't just show up with a bunch of ingredients and be like, "Cook. Now" You'd honestly get soup if that occurred. And I mean from scratch roux based Gumbo to show you how real Gumbo is made.
review.author: Joyce G.

review.description: Love the farmer's market on any day of the year! Such a wonderful part of living here in Madison :)
review.author: Anonymous L.

review.description:
I cannot believe I have not reviewed this market- have been here at least 4 times during my visits and each time I found amazing foods!
Fall season is possibly my favorite because of the good variety of vendors..
This last time was in late October- emu jerky and wool for knitting caught my eye, so I returned to LA with unique items to share.
Gourds, cheese, pumpkins, cakes, causes to which to donate, uniquely costumed people, apples, candies, and flowers are captivating. 
We may have year round farmers' markets in California however the beauty of Madison and this unique location at the Capitol is a winner!
Now to get Mr. Walker out of the atmosphere and all will be perfect!!
review.author: Ellen O.

review.description: Supposedly the largest farmers market in the country. The amazjngness dep new on the season, but there's always so much cheese. Get there early if you expect to get curds, though, by midday everyone is sold out--they must sell thousands of pounds of cheese curds each weekend. There ate lots of potted flowers early in the spring, and the produce shows up later. The cheese sampling is epic. Hard to run in and out, and it takes a couple of laps.
review.author: Mira S.

review.description:
this is such an amazing place. the largest farmer's market in America, and the place stretches for miles around the wisconsin state capitol with stores peddling the best produce around. 

we were there just a week ago, and the market was bursting with ripe cherries (so dark and juicy they were like jelly), heirloom tomatoes (always the right choice over the modern varieties - get the multicoloured baskets), and beautiful produce we don't get in Singapore, like kale in big (cheap) amounts, rainbow beets and fresh corn. 

this is dairy land of course, so you'll see plenty of vendors serving up cheese in its various forms: curd (eew - totally not for me), hard cheeses, and even cheeses mixed into with ingredients for pan-frying or baking (be sure to get those!) 

and this IS America, so there are sugar cookies and (too-) sweet confectionaries in trays upon trays, cinnamon rolls the size of your face and breads so big you could play rugby with. 

I took away one star because I was hoping for some cooked food - barbecue, paella, sort of what london's borough market has - and you want that savoriness to counteract all the sweet. but it's a great visit in a weekend morning (bring your hat because it gets hot!) and the fruit is crazy cheap (especially since I'm used to paying for imported produce).
review.author: Sonya C.

review.description: The gold standard for farmer's markets. But sometimes you don't want to deal with crowds on a Saturday at 8 am. You want to wake up late and hate on people from afar. But let's say you aren't me--you should go to the farmer's market and judge families, hipsters, and food up close. You'll thank me. Just don't expect me to be present.
review.author: El P.

review.description:
Tip Number 1 - Go with the flow. For visitors the salmon flow counterclockwise around the capital.

Tip Number 2 - You'll need cash. Look for a UW  Credit Union ATM. They are free, no charge machines.

Besides that have fun. The spicy cheese bread is very popular. We also love the hedgerow jam, spicy pickles, cheese curds and bakery.

Everything closes down at 1pm, but some vendors will run out of things and close down closer to noon. So get there early.
review.author: Justin M.

review.description:
The Dane County Farmer's Market is in my "1,000 Places to See in the U.S.A. & Canada Before You Die" book. It is 100% worth checking out!  The DCRM  allows only Wisconsin agriculturally related items. So not a lot of mangos but lots of good Cheese and other things you would expect from Wisconsin.  

TIPS: I would bring cash (though some venders take cards),  ALSO walk counter clockwise around the square!  (don't be that guy...  don't do it)  & some times of year it can be wall to wall people so just keep that in mind.
review.author: Chris M.

review.description:
The Quintessential Madison Experience

I've lived in Madison for over 30 years now and I have to say that the Dane County Farmers Market in late summer / early fall is my absolute fave Madison experience.  Armed with a couple of totes, a cup of coffee and a pastry (or two) from Batch Bakehouse, my daughter and I always seem to hit the market when the crowds hit their peak and we love every minute of our slow stroll around the Capitol Square.  We talk about the past week, I share fatherly insights on how to shop for produce and we jointly plan our weekly menu on the spot as we see what's in season that week.  I can't think of a better way to bond with my daughter and kick off the weekend.

While everyone has their personal favorite aspects of the market, here are a couple of mine:
* Every trip to the market starts with a Farmer John's curd run.  Best curds in the land, bar none.
* Even though I have absolutely no room in my garden for new plants, I always end up browsing through the perennials at the Flower Factory.  And I appreciate that the staff is always willing to answer any questions I have about the plague or pestilence threatening to do in my garden beds.
* Try as I may, I am physically unable to make my journey around the square without sampling the fine cheeses from Hook's.   Anything dish I cook with cheese always tastes better when I use their products.
* The Green Barn Farm stand located at the corner of Mifflin and Wisconsin Ave is where I start picking up my produce.  I'm partial to them since I grew up not far from where they operate and their prices are always competitive.

I'm swimming against the flow here, but the Spicy Cheese bread from Stella's is vastly overrated.  Do yourself a favor, and instead of blowing $8 on an undercooked loaf of bread with a couple nuggets of melted cheese, buy some aged cheddar from Hook's or some chevre from Capri and pair it with a baguette from Batch or Madison Sourdough.   Unlike the dough blob from Stella's that hardens into an inedible brick after 30 minutes, you'll be able to enjoy this treat all afternoon.  Trust me, do this once and you'll never go back.

After wrapping up a lap or two around the square, there are a variety of activities you can do: maybe brunch at Marigold or Graze, a bike ride around Lake Monona, a leisurely stroll down State Street or maybe a tour through the Capitol to soak in the Madison experience.  It's all good...
review.author: Matt W.

review.description:
ABSOLUTELY LOVE the Madison Farmer's Market!
You cannot leave without trying Stella's Spicy Cheese bread. I may not be the person to ask about produce considering I typical go there to by dairy, meat, bakery products. A recent find we had this past weekend was Carmel Corn Gelato!  It is a fun place to wonder around and have breakfast. If you want to get in and get out without a lot of people it is best to go in the morning if you have kids, strollers, walkers go after 9 am when the pace is more a leisurely walk and you aren't getting in the way of the people who want to get what they need and leave. 
Enjoy!
review.author: Nichole C.

review.description:
I've been back for a second, third, fourth, and fifth go-around, and the transformation throughout the summer season and into the fall is truly amazing.

The entire atmosphere of the farmer's market is completely different during the summer. The selection of produce is much more expansive: fruits, veggies, herbs, meats, cheeses, etc. There is also a wide array of non-edible items for sell as well. BABY GOURDS MAMA GOURDS. GOURDS GALOURD!! (get it? hehe) Summer bouquet for me? Aww shucks, you shouldn't have!

I've been much, much more impressed by the array of purchasable items the last few times I have gone. Bravo, DCFM, bravo! I only wish you were here to stay...
review.author: Sherry L.

review.description: Wow, I had heard the buzz and as a Chicagoan have been wanting to come visit just to visit the farmer's market and it was well worth it! I will be back to hang out and pick up farmers market finds as soon as I can! It was cold and rainy and windy and miserable out but I still managed to have an amazing time and load up on pumpkins and squash and honey and other veggies that would make the trip home to Chicago.
review.author: Charlie B.

review.description: Definitely a highlight of my visit to sweet Madison. Walking with the crowd around the beautiful capitol building, enjoying it from every angle while checking out the incredible produce on display. This is North America's largest producer-only market apparently, and you can feel the pride busting from the seams and between the leaves. The baked goods are particularly awesome, with the biggest donuts I have ever seen, and an excited lineup of people waiting to get their hands on hot spicy cheese bread. It moves inside when it gets cold, so enjoy it during the summer and in the fall when it's extra gloriously gourd-filled.
review.author: Risa D.

review.description:
Whenever I talk about Madison to someone out of town, they always say "I hear there is a great Farmer's Market"

Right they are.  There are few like it.

Take the entire Capital square, and line it with local vendors.  It's quite the experience.

Here's what to expect:  Fresh produce, meats, breads, cheeses, flowers, and more all produced within a short drive of Madison.  You'll also get samples of many of those items.  

You are going to pay a lot more for stuff than what you'd pay the grocery store, but the point here is not to save money.  It's to contribute to sustainable farm-to-fork production.  You're typically getting organic, free range, well-cared for food.   You'll find many items far tastier than what you'd find at the store as well.

Pro tip:  Get there before 9AM or else you'll face massive crowds.  Also, leave the dogs at home, as they are not allowed.
review.author: Kevin T.

review.description:
You think you've been to a farmers market, and then you stop by the DCFM and realize that you haven't been to THE farmers market. Every time I have been in the Madison area I made it a point to visit. Now that I live here I think I will forever be spoiled.

The market runs year round and the vendors seem to be always changing. You can find fresh flowers, fresh cheese (cheese curds!), honey, pickled goods, baked goods, and of course fresh fruits and vegetables. Slightly off of the square they have the arts and crafty booths. 

We typically go early. Around 9-9:30am the crowd really starts to pick up. I'd definitely recommend getting there early; you can stop and talk to the vendors. Most of them are passionate about what they are selling. Pick up some baked goods while you're there and eat while you browse. There's ample samples, too. Everyone stops for Stella's cheesy bread, if you've never had it it might be worth the 8 bucks to see what all the hype is about. 

Bring a decent sized bag with you to hold all of your goodies; lots of smaller bills for paying; remember to walk to clockwise, it won't be difficult to do since everyone else is doing it; do some quick research when it comes to parking, and if you opt for a meter be sure to check your watch as time goes fast. 

We usually like to walk around first and see what we'd like. There's nothing wrong with comparing prices, as sometimes they do vary.
review.author: Daisy D.

review.description: the best farmers market i have ever been to, it's actually the largest in the country from what i've been told. i got there pretty early, probably around 8am, and it wasn't super crowded which was nice. first stop was obviously stellas for the famous spicy cheesy bread, and let me just tell you, it did not disappoint. there were tons of amazing flowers and plants, and a TON of cheese with free samples. i got cheese buzzed so early and i did not hate it. ended up buying a tangy blue cheese for olive stuffing for the night's later martinis. also bought massive sunflowers for my aunt. this is a must see when you are in madison! not to mention, the people are just so friendly and more than willing to chat and answer any questions!
review.author: Alyssa M.

review.description:
I want to love it.  I just can't.  I know, I know, I am practically committing a sin.

If you are new to the city, figuring out parking is horrendous.  Please place signs on the parking garages which state which is cash, card or change.  It is difficult to have a good time when you are worried about parking.  

I love the theme weeks, Cows on the Square is my favorite.  When they have music stages, I tend to stay away.  It is too loud and ruins the feel of the day.  

What do I dislike?  The strollers.  I have been clipped on my heels more time than I can count.  I get it, kids are heavy.  However, if you have to bring them, please be courteous.
